div.p: The firstfour notes of this piece are to be played unbroken, with four full and short strokes, and on the fifth one should do a sharp trill in the lowest octave. The following measure is played as it is written. The first six notes in the fourth measure have to be doubled with octaves, and in the right hand the figure, that follows immediately in the bass, has to be used:

In the last half of the mentioned fourth measure the right hand has to play six times per quarter note. This is to be done in all similiar cases. Those quarter notes are, as you can see, composed of eight notes. I remember this, since it might appear strange to the reader, that in just one quarter note on should play six times with the right hand. The fifth bar wants octaves again and the above mentioned, transposed figure, starting with an e. With that do start the sixth and seventh measure as well, each in its own tonality.

The eighth bar develops the described interlude three times in ascending degrees in the right hand, while the bass is doubled, in this way:
In the ninth bar the entrance motive comes in again. Here the discant can easily find a subtle melody in eighth notes and the bass can be played full-voiced. In the tenth bar one must not forget the trill on the first; For the eleventh there is nothing to remember.

The twelfth bar wants to be played full-voiced in the bass, while the right hand can make use of everything that has been there in the previous bar only by changing the g to an d and goes on. The thirteenth bar is to be played as written: and the first half of the fourteenth requires one to begin with a little interlude in the discant in the following way:
The same can be done a note lower in the first half of the fifteenth bar and in the seventeenth bar one only has to observe what has been said in the § 1.

Now we have indicated in § 3. how to deal with notes as they show up again the b. 21; if, however, somebody wants to do a variation here, it will be even more pleasant to listen to. Once more a trill in b. 22 shall be recommended, i.e. in the low octave. It cannot do harm if somebody wants to try this trill simultaneously in the right hand in sixths.

In b. 25 occurs once more the simple motive of the beginning. Since it can be heard for the fourth time it fairly deserves an ornamentation in the right hand. The usual counter-motive has to be taken fro the fourth bar in my opinion, and should be played there as well as here:
From this one can see, that these things are not just whims, empty motives, unordered and wild ideas or dry basses: but everything is connected, there is almost no note to find that is without relation to the others. After having played to counter-motive a couple of times it can be varyied for the third and fourth time in that way.

Was has been there in b. 23 come in again in b. 26, b. 27 and b. 28 with the necessary changes. The last six notes in b. 30 require a special discant. And then one can play to end as firmly as the fingers can.
